div1.p: Geisel writes to his sister about his new activity of drilling fresh recruits from nascent units.

I received a letter from you some time ago, which I have neglected to answer as I have been very buisy this while past. I have in my charge 25 new recruits belonging to Co. L, a new Co. which is being formed for our regiment, and it keeps me buisy from morning till night to attend to them. In the fornoon I have to go out with them on a foot drill, and in the afternoon we have a mounted drill. This morning about 9 O'clock it commenced to snow, and it is still snowing yet, 4 o'clock and we will therefore not go out on drill this afternoon, so I thought I would write you a letter, although I have not much news to tell you for we are now almost in the sea of our army and hardly know what is going on in front. I wrote a
letter to sister Hannah a few days ago which I suppose she has received by this time. I received one letter from Amanda, which I answered when we were at Williamsport, but I have not received any letter from her since, and Anne has not wrote to me yet. I would be very glad to receive a letter from her and I heard that Spencer Brand was very sick. I am anxious to hear how he is by this time. We have a young fellow in Co. H by the name of James and I dondt doubt but what you know him and there is one in Co. L named Flechenstein, he used to live at the cowpath road, perhaps you know him, and Charles Johnson the Blacksmith, who used to live in Line Lexington is in Co. M but neither of them knew me any more. Charles Johnson lived at square and was drafted, and as soon as he was drafted he enlisted in this regiment. he has been here a little over a week.
I have not heard from the 104th Penn. since we came into Maryland; if you have heard from any of them, I would be glad to hear how they are getting along and where they are. has Searg. Mathis gone to his regiment yet? I got my Photograph taken at Frederick and enclosed you will find one if you will please to except of it. I must now bring my letter to a close, hoping that it may find you all in as good health as I enjoy at present. Give my best respects to all enquiring friends. my compliments and love to all the family at home. I remain
